subject: Re: testXXXX must return void?

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Wenner <robert@p...> wrote:
> I am not sure if I got you right here.
> Why do you use that inspector? To /manually/ verify the /automated/ 
> test did not fail? Collecting test results (whether tests fail or 
pass) is JUnit's job, not the tester's -- that's why it is an 
automated test.  

I think we are coming from different places. Maybe its my Smalltalk 
background. I dont want to get too OT but maybe a specific example 
will help. I'm now in early development of a mapping a business 
object model in TOPLink. I want to evaluate expressions which read my 
objects from the db to test my mappings. If that doesnt blow up (and 
it does, a LOT, right now), I want to play around with that instance 
in an inspector, send messages to it, fix the toString(), test lazy 
instantiation of its parts, add some behavior, debug, etc, all in the 
context of a live instance. In short I want to _interact_ with the 
object.

However since I am going to the trouble to create this test code 
which produces those objects, I would like to institutionalize those 
snippets into a test suite so I and other team members can reuse them 
easily in the same manner. That's why I dont want the code in a 
scrapbook window. I'm less interested in the automated test aspect 
right now. 

For other projects I have worked differently. For example, 
I built a Java parser and all I needed were automated tests 
(thousands of them). I didnt have to interact with any objects. I 
usually just asserted that the parsetree toString() looked like the 
source string (actually this happened to be in Smalltalk with sUnit). 
So I am familiar with that way of working as well.


> I don't understand what you mean by cataloging.

I mean I want to elevate my test artifacts from workspacewindow 
snippets to code which is managed by the version control system (Envy 
etc), available to team members, etc. And yes for automated testing 
eventually. 

> Neither do I understand what bothers you about having tests in the 
> development workspace. After all, tests belong to the development?

I hope I clarified this above and also the premise that one might not 
only or even primarily be interested in the automation aspect of 
junit for a given situation.

> It's in src.jar in the JUnit directory.

Thanks very much.
